name: Brian Samuel
comment info: first finding in this graph was that Japan leads the world in life expectancy, despite spending less on healthcare than several other major European countries and the United States. India spends amongst the least on health expenditures and also has the lowest life expectancy. The US, however, spends the greatest amount yet has a lower life expectancy than many other nations. These observations led to several questions on the state of health expenditures worldwide. First, do the health expenditures reflect how much consumers are spending on healthcare or an individual government? Furthermore, could the lifestyle and choices of individual citizens affect average life expectancy regardless of how much a country spends on healthcare? And lastly, how do countries such as China, Italy, and Japan maintain a higher life expectancy despite spending far less on health expenditures? The statistics of this graph lead to a deeper story with many important lessons that affect our country. As an American, it is important that our government is utilizing its health expenditures and funding in a way that best benefits the public. Unfortunately, despite spending nearly $10,000 per capita on healthcare, the results on life expectancy have largely plateaued. By studying countries such as Japan and Switzerland, we can learn methods that can increase life expectancy and better influence our decisions. I would title this graph: “The Price of Life.”

name: Zayd A
comment info: When I looked over the graph, I noticed that the countries that spent over $4,000 per capita look a lot different on the graph than the countries that spent below $2,000 per capita. First off, the <2,000 countries only spent an average of $11.20 per capita per each year of life expectancy. You could say that means the populations of the <2,000 countries spend an average $11.20 spent for each year of life expectancy. What about the >4,000 countries? Well, they average a lofty $75.50 per capita per each year of life expectancy, which is nearly seven times what the >2,000 countries spend. That is quite a difference. There must be a reason, possibly benefit for spending this much more. Well, there is. The <2,000 countries average a life expectancy of ~73 years while the heavy-spending >4,000 countries average a life expectancy of ~82 years. So their benefit for spending six times as more is nine extra years of life expectancy. Is it worth it? I’m not sure, because there are so many other variables.

name: Katie C.
comment info:
Is the U.S. wasting its money on healthcare? According to a graph I analyzed, the United States spends the most money on healthcare. It showed the correlation between life expectancy at birth and healthcare expenditure per capita between thirteen countries. The United States spends roughly $3.3 billion a year on health care alone and our life expectancy is 79 years old on average.   To most, this might seem reasonable, but Japan's life expectancy on average is five years longer, and they only spend $630 million a year. That is five times less than what we spend annually. Like Japan, France, Canada, Italy, and Germany all spend between four to five thousand dollars per capita and have a life expectancy above 80. What are we doing wrong? 
	Japan requires all of its residents to join their healthcare system as a category called statutory insurance. This requires them to apply for healthcare on one of the 1447 plans available. It's paid for by tax revenue, allowing the average person to only spend $5,000 a year. In the U.S. the average person spends $10,000 a year on healthcare insurance. To receive healthcare benefits you must apply unlike in Japan where it is mandatory for everyone. The U.S. has roughly 37 million people who do not have healthcare insurance. Making people aware of the differences in each countries healthcare policy might make us change how we view healthcare.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Katie C. This is so true! I read an article about the price difference in American Healthcare procedures and prescriptions versus other countries. (Here is one link to support this information -https://www.healthsystemtracker.org/chart-collection/how-do-healthcare-prices-and-use-in-the-u-s-compare-to-other-countries/#item-start) Privatized Insurance allows for costs to be driven up for the general public as insurance companies make deals with healthcare providers to lower costs by agreeing to only pay a certain cost for certain procedures/prescriptions. The average person, without insurance, can't afford these egregiously high prices and will choose to not pursue healthcare, even when absolutely necessary.  Who knows what the life expectancy could look like if healthcare costs would reflect the actual labor, education and tools used to perform the work, therefore allowing more people access to healthcare.

name: Sloane W.
comment info:
Life expectancy is not something a lot of people think about. The people who do think about it most, assume that if they live in a wealthy country then they will live longer than those who do not. After examining a graph, about average life expectancies and the amount spent on medical care I was very surprised. The graph shows how much a country on average would spend on medical care and how long their average life expectancies are. I saw that the two variables have zero correlation. For example, the United States citizens are spending the most on medical care but on average are living less long than those who live in Japan, Italy, France, Switzerland, Germany, and Canada.
	 I think that some of the reasons other countries have a longer life expectancy than the United States are because of the environment of those countries. According to U.S.News, the best countries by the quality of life and social purpose in rank are Canada, Japan, Germany, Switzerland, Australia, United States, New Zealand, United Kingdom, Sweden, and the Netherlands. This makes me wonder if the lurking variable is quality of life and social purpose. It also makes me think that in the United States we have less of a positive quality of life than those countries. In the United States, everyone is always competing against each other to best at your job or to be the most popular. I think that in the countries that put less importance on making money and being popular the citizens are happier and live longer.

replies.name: K
replies.comment info: @Sloane W. I agree. I would’ve thought that the more money that you spend on healthcare the better care and longer life you would live. Think that your idea on quality of life is a great lurking variable. Much like the Rosetans in Malcom Gladwell’s Outliers.

replies.name: C
replies.comment info: @Sloane W. Not to mention the day-to-day grind here in America. Other countries take long holidays at least twice a year. So many people in America feel they can never use their vacation days because there isn't enough time, support at their job, or support from their supervisors. Self-care is often preached but also very often ignored in the work environment. People will sacrifice their mental health, physical health, and overall well-being for either the all mighty dollar or so that they can provide the bare minimum for their families. Think of families barely making ends meet too! In some of these families the parents work multiple jobs just to take care of their family, still can barely make ends meet and can definitely not feel like they can sacrifice a single day of work. Hourly employees often don't have vacation days to use anyway so every hour away from work is an hour of money lost. Capitalism has many upsides but a huge downside is the rat race and inability to savor life that much of the American working population (and students too!) must endure in order to keep up with even basic necessities in life.

name: Brooke, Rose, Sarah
comment info:
“Life Expectancy vs. Health Expenditures” 

Our group noticed many things about this graph. For one, mostly European countries have the highest life expectancy. Another thing we noticed was that the lines for each country move around a lot but level out more at the top. We also saw that the countries are split into 2 relative groups, one with lower life expectancies and one with higher. The group with lower life expectancies mainly has countries in Eastern Europe or Asia. Lastly, we noticed that many countries spend less on healthcare compared to the US, yet still have higher life expectancies than us. Next, we thought about what the graph shows. We wonder why most European countries live longer than everyone else. We also wondered why the US has a lower life expectancy at birth, but a higher health expenditure per capita. Lastly, we wondered what factors contribute to Japan having the highest life expectancy at birth. Then we thought about what impact this has on our community. This impacts us and our community as the life expectancy is slightly lower than most countries for the United States and we are spending a lot of money on healthcare compared to other countries. The curve line for the U.S. was moving up and now it appears that it is going back down. Ultimately, the United States has some room for improvement when it comes to healthcare.

name: Grace U, Kaitlin B, Evan D, Brian S
comment info: This graph shows the average life expectancy at birth and the average health expenditure per capita. Our group noticed that Japan tends to have the greatest life expectancy despite spending far less on health expenditures. On the contrary, we noticed that the United States spends an average of $10,000 per capita, but has an expected life expectancy of 78. We found that many Eastern and Asian countries spend far less on health than the West, yet have relatively high life expectancies. We wondered: Would the air quality in China affect an overall life expectancy? name: Emma T, Ali T, Ian B, and Karah S
comment info:
Title: The Health Care Gap

We notice that Switzerland spends lots of money but also has a high life expectancy so they are getting their money's worth. China, Brazil, Ukraine, India, and the Russian Federation have very low high expectancy and low health care spending. The United States is the only country that doesn't seem to fit with the curve. We wonder why the U.S. spends so much on health care expenditure, and yet Japan is living longer? Finally, we wonder what other factors perhaps help people live longer. name: Dylan
comment info:
I think that maybe the United States spends more money on healthcare per capita as it is a privatised, for-profit system. In almost all other countries, there is some form of Universal Healthcare and I suppose that healthcare is cheaper as a result. Governments are unlikely to try to squeeze profit out of citizens whereas, for the private sector, it is vital. 
Of the countries who have higher life expectancy (that are shown), all but Switzerland are in the G8, proving that more developed economies have an improved life expectancy as they are the only countries who can afford the greater health expenditure. Compared to the high income countries, the United States falls behind. Perhaps the world's biggest GDP does not automatically equal longer life.
Also, many of the lower expenditure countries have very quickly increased life expectancy judging by the steep gradient of the line, showing that they are developing at speed. The extra money spent at a lower level looks far more effective  at  increasing lifespan than when the country already spends a lot.
We can also see how Japan has a world-leading life-expectancy, maybe this is what is causing there old person crisis.
